rules: Rule1: Provided that an insurance policy meets premium payment, if it is not the case that a production having a force majeure event would imply that the non-occurrence of an actor having a schedule conflict would lead to an actor being available, thereby resulting in a production being delayed, then a producer receives compensation.

Rule2: In the event that an insurance policy has valid coverage, if it is not true that a production having a force majeure event would lead to the situation where the absence of an actor having a schedule conflict implies an actor is available, which in turn implies a production is delayed, then a producer receives compensation.
Rule3: Under the condition that policy type A is active, an insurance policy meets premium payment.
Rule4: Either policy type A is active or policy type B is active.
Rule5: If policy type B is active, then an insurance policy has valid coverage.
Rule6: Whenever a film has copyright protection, the film has trademark registration.

Rule7: Either a technology has patent pending, or if a film has trademark registration, then under the condition that a project not being greenlit does not lead to an actor not having a contract with a studio, a studio gets legal protection.
Rule8: If an actor is available, then it is not the case that the actor has a contract with a studio.
Rule9: Provided that a project loses sponsorship, the project secures sponsorship.

Rule10: In the case that a project has a marketing campaign, if it is not true that either a brand has product placement or that a project being financed would lead to an actor having a schedule conflict implying the actor is available, then the project loses sponsorship.

Rule11: Under the condition that a project has a PR strategy, if it is not the case that a brand has product placement or that a project being financed would result in an actor having a schedule conflict meaning the actor is available, then the project loses sponsorship.
Rule12: Whenever a studio is a major studio, a project has a marketing campaign.
Rule13: Either a studio is a major studio or a studio is an independent studio.
Rule14: If a studio is an independent studio, then a project has a PR strategy.
Rule15: Should a project be financed, it has budget approval.
Rule16: In the event that a project has budget approval, an actor having a schedule conflict results in the actor being available.
Rule17: If a production is delayed, then the production needs rescheduling.
Rule18: Given that a production has an insurance claim, if an actor having a schedule conflict does not imply the actor is available, then the production is delayed.
Rule19: Either a production has an insurance claim or a production has a force majeure event.

Rule20: In the case that it is not true that either a brand has product placement or that a project being financed would cause an actor having a schedule conflict to imply the actor is available, a project does not secure sponsorship.
Rule21: If it is not the case that an actor having a schedule conflict results in the actor being available, then a production does not need rescheduling.

Rule22: In the event that it is not the case that a production having a force majeure event would result in the situation where an actor not having a schedule conflict implies the actor is available, thereby causing a production to be delayed, a producer does not receive compensation.
Rule23: Should the scenario where a project is not greenlit not necessitate an actor lacking a contract with a studio, then a studio does not get legal protection.
Rule24: If a project is not greenlit, then an actor has a contract with a studio.
Rule25: In the case that a project is not greenlit, an actor has a schedule conflict.
facts: Fact1: A film has copyright protection.
Fact3: A technology does not have patent pending.
Fact4: A brand does not have product placement.
